Historical and Conceptual Setting

Schleiermacher’s doctrine of God emerges from his basic methodological decision: theology is a disciplined account of the self-consciousness (piety) of the Christian community, not an exposition of a prior, objectively given divine self-revelation in word and act. Under Kantian and Romantic influence, he relocates theology from metaphysics to religious experience.

By contrast, the Reformed, classical-theist, Nicene–Chalcedonian tradition begins with the triune Lord who is antecedently and objectively real, who speaks and acts in the economy of creation, covenant, incarnation, and redemption, and whose self-communication in Scripture norms the church’s experience.

This contrast is sharply focused in two loci: Schleiermacher’s notion of God as “Whence” and his systematic marginalization of the Trinity, vis-à-vis a confessional Reformed doctrine of the personal, triune Lord.

Schleiermacher: God as “Whence” and Trinity at the Periphery

God as “Whence” and feeling of absolute dependence

For Schleiermacher:

  • Religion is neither knowing (metaphysics) nor doing (morality), but immediate self-consciousness, specifically the Gefühl der schlechthinnigen Abhängigkeit: the feeling of absolute dependence.
  • This feeling is universal and pre-conceptual. It gives us not propositions about God but an immediate awareness that our being is conditioned by an ultimate ground.
  • God, therefore, is the “Whence” of this dependence: the absolutely conditioning ground of our existence. God is not first described as a personal “Thou,” but as the transcendent source presupposed in our self-awareness.
  • Doctrines of God’s attributes, will, and relation to the world are second-order, reflective descriptions of this primary religious consciousness. They are “accounts of the modifications of the Christian self-consciousness,” not disclosures of God as he is in himself.

This yields a functional and asymmetrical personalism: God as Whence may later be described in personal categories, but the primary datum is not God’s self-speaking Lordship, but human piety under an ultimate dependence.

Marginalization of the Trinity

Consistently, Schleiermacher:

  • Structures his Dogmatics from Christian consciousness inward, not from the economic missions of Son and Spirit back to the immanent Trinity.
  • Treats the Trinity not as the architectonic principle of Christian doctrine but as a reflective, late-arriving construction summarizing the experienced efficacy of Christ and the Spirit in the community.
  • Relegates Trinitarian doctrine to an appendix-like position: it does not control the exposition of God, creation, revelation, sin, Christology, or redemption.
  • Interprets traditional Trinitarian language as symbolic of the way the one God is experienced in the community (as ground, as in Christ, as in the Spirit’s operation), not as a revealed account of God’s eternal, personal life.

The result is monotheism of consciousness with Trinitarianism as a historically conditioned, experiential grammar, not as ontological truth concerning the eternal being of God.

Classical Reformed, Nicene–Chalcedonian Doctrine: Personal Triune Lord

Ontological starting point: Lord before “Whence”

In Reformed, classical theism:

  • God is the living, personal Lord who exists a se, in himself, prior to any relation to the creature. His being is not derived from, nor first known as, a correlate of human consciousness.
  • Scripture presents God as one who speaks, wills, commands, promises, judges, and saves. Personal agency and covenant lordship are primordial, not derivative projections from human feeling.
  • Human dependence is real and radical, but it is covenantal dependence on a personal Lord. The “Whence” of our being is the triune “Thou” who freely creates and addresses us.

Thus, a Reformed account can speak analogously of absolute dependence, but it is dependence on the God who preexists and explains that dependence by his own triune being and decree, rather than being explained by it.

Trinity as architectonic, not appendicial

Nicene–Chalcedonian and Reformed theology hold that:

  • The one God is eternally Father, Son, and Holy Spirit: one simple essence, three distinct, coequal, consubstantial persons.
  • This triune life is known by revelation in the economy: the Father sending the Son and the Spirit, the Son’s incarnation, death, resurrection, and exaltation, the Spirit’s indwelling and uniting work.
  • The Trinity is not merely how God appears in consciousness; it is how God is in himself, albeit known analogically and ectypally.
  • Therefore, the Trinity is not an optional capstone; it is the organizing principle:
  • Doctrine of God: divine unity and simplicity understood as the one essence subsisting in three persons.
  • Creation and providence: the Father through the Son in the Spirit.
  • Revelation and Scripture: the Father speaking in the Son by the Spirit.
  • Christology and soteriology: incarnate Son, mediating Spirit, adoption to the Father.
  • Ecclesiology and sacramentology: Spirit gathering to the Son in the presence of the Father.

In Reformed confessionalism, the Trinity is “summed up” at the end only because it has silently governed everything from the beginning; Schleiermacher’s procedure is the inverse.

Doctrinal Analysis and Evaluation

Ontology and epistemology of God

  • Schleiermacher’s God-as-Whence concept:
  • Epistemologically: God is accessible only within the horizon of religious self-consciousness; no direct metaphysical or propositional grasp is possible beyond what experience yields.
  • Ontologically: God’s being-in-himself is formally affirmed but materially inaccessible; theology cannot properly elaborate it.
  • Reformed classical theism:
  • Insists on archetypal/ectypal distinction: God’s being is fully known to himself (archetypal theology); we possess a finite, analogical, yet true knowledge derived from revelation (ectypal theology).
  • Rejects the collapse of theology into anthropology: revealed propositions about God’s being, will, and attributes are about God, not about our states of consciousness.

Schleiermacher effectively subordinates ontology to phenomenology; Reformed theology maintains that phenomenological accounts of piety must be normed and corrected by ontological revelation.

Personhood and the triune Lord

  • Schleiermacher’s starting point in dependence tends to yield a unipersonal or suprapersonal absolute:
  • The “Whence” is the one absolute causality behind all finite causal series.
  • Personal-relational language is second-order, generated from communal experience of Christ and the Spirit.
  • Nicene–Reformed doctrine begins with concrete hypostases:
  • The Father who elects, the Son who redeems, the Spirit who applies redemption.
  • The name “Lord” is triune: “one Lord Jesus Christ” confessed within the Shema’s “one God,” and the Spirit confessed as “the Lord and giver of life.”

Hence, in Reformed terms, Schleiermacher’s account tends toward a functional modalism at the level of consciousness and a vague monotheism at the level of ontology, lacking robust, eternally distinct persons.

Trinity’s location in the system

  • Schleiermacher’s appendix-like placement of the Trinity signals that:
  • The triune name does not structure the doctrine of God’s attributes.
  • Creation, providence, and redemption do not require explicitly triune exposition as such; “Trinity” labels the highest form of Christian God-consciousness.
  • In classical dogmatics:
  • The Trinity is the grammar in which every other locus is properly uttered.
  • To treat the Trinity as marginal is to misdescribe Christian faith itself, which is baptism into the name of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

From a Reformed standpoint, Schleiermacher’s system is therefore materially subtrinitarian, even where it verbally retains Trinitarian language.

  • If theology is fundamentally self-interpretation of piety, then:
  • Dogma loses its status as God’s authoritative self-interpretation and becomes historical expression of communal consciousness.
  • The objectivity of the gospel—God’s triune action in Christ and the Spirit—is relativized to its efficacy in generating God-consciousness.
  • In Reformed, Nicene–Chalcedonian thought:
  • The gospel is first an objective history of triune action, attested in inspired Scripture.
  • Our consciousness of God is the fruit, not the source or measure, of that reality; piety is a response to the already-true triune Lordship of God.

critical_doctrinal_themes.question: Sin, Christology, and atonement: Schleiermacher’s view of sin as disturbance of God-consciousness, Christ as bearer of perfect God-consciousness, and non-penal atonement versus Reformed doctrines of guilt, wrath, penal substitution, imputation, and orthodox Christology.
critical_doctrinal_themes.answer_markdown:
## Schleiermacher’s Dogmatic Structure

Schleiermacher’s entire dogmatics is organized around **God-consciousness** rather than a juridical or covenantal framework.

- **Religion as feeling of absolute dependence.** For Schleiermacher, the essence of religion is not knowledge or obedience but the immediate self-consciousness of being absolutely dependent on the “Whence” of our existence. This is not an inference from the world but a primitive datum of consciousness.
- **Sin as disturbance.** Sin is not first defined as guilt before a holy Lawgiver but as a **disturbance, obstruction, or weakening** of God-consciousness. It is a defect in the religious self-awareness of the subject, which then manifests socially and ethically.
- **Christ as archetype.** Christ is the one in whom God-consciousness is absolutely perfect, constant, and victorious. His uniqueness lies not primarily in his ontological constitution (though Schleiermacher does not deny this) but in his perfect God-consciousness that exerts a redemptive influence on the community.

Thus, soteriology and Christology are functions of religious experience: Christ’s person and work are interpreted by their efficacy in producing and restoring God-consciousness in the church.

## Sin and Guilt: Schleiermacher versus Reformed Theology

### Schleiermacher on sin

- **Ontological-psychological focus.** Sin is a universal condition in which the natural self-consciousness (self-activity, self-love) disorders and occludes God-consciousness. The key category is **power** or **influence** rather than guilt: sin is a power propagated through historical-human solidarity.
- **No primary juridical relation.** The fundamental problem is not violation of divine law and consequent liability to punishment, but estrangement from God as the Whence of our being. Talk of “guilt” is retained only as a secondary moral description of this disturbance.

### Reformed doctrine of sin

Within classic Reformed theology:

- **Sin as lawlessness.** Sin is fundamentally **transgression of God’s law** and **enmity against God**, not merely a disturbance of religious consciousness. It is ethically and covenantally defined.
- **Guilt and corruption.** Original sin has a **forensic** aspect (Adam’s guilt imputed to his posterity) and a **habitual** aspect (inherited corruption). Both are essential: we are liable to punishment and internally depraved.
- **Divine wrath.** Because God is righteous and personal, sin arouses real **wrath**—God’s holy, settled opposition to evil. Wrath is not reducible to subjective experience of estrangement; it is an objective divine response within the covenantal relation.

The contrast is fundamental: Schleiermacher relocates sin from a juridical-covenantal register into a phenomenology of experience; the Reformed tradition insists that subjective disturbance presupposes and expresses an objective breach of covenant, guilt, and exposure to judgment.

## Christology: God-Consciousness and Orthodox Dogma

### Schleiermacher’s functional Christology

- **Christ’s unbroken God-consciousness.** Christ is the one in whom God-consciousness is absolutely perfect and uninterrupted. His “sinlessness” is conceptualized as the complete dominion of God-consciousness over all impulses.
- **Redemptive efficacy by communication.** Salvation occurs as Christ’s perfect God-consciousness exerts a formative influence on the community, communicating itself by the Spirit so that believers’ consciousness is gradually conformed to his.
- **Doctrine of two natures.** Schleiermacher formally retains Chalcedonian language but reinterprets it:
  - The **divine nature** is effectively equated with the absolute God-consciousness.
  - The **human nature** is the finite, historically conditioned psychological life in which this consciousness appears.
  - The hypostatic union functions to explain the uniqueness and universality of Christ’s religious influence rather than to secure ontological assumptions needed for substitutionary atonement.

Thus, Christ is ontologically unique, but the **center of gravity** moves from metaphysics to religious experience and historical efficacy.

### Reformed orthodox Christology

Reformed orthodoxy, following the ecumenical councils, holds:

- **True God, true man.** The Son is consubstantial with the Father and consubstantial with us, two complete natures united in one person without confusion or change.
- **An-hypostasis/en-hypostasis.** Christ’s human nature has no independent personal subsistence but subsists in the eternal person of the Logos.
- **Instrumentality for atonement.** The two-natures Christology is not merely a way of stating religious uniqueness; it is necessary so that:
  - As man he can stand under the law and in the place of sinners.
  - As God his obedience and sufferings possess infinite worth and can be efficacious for many.

Schleiermacher’s emphasis on God-consciousness tends to **psychologize** the incarnation; Reformed dogmatics insists that the ontological incarnation grounds objective substitution and covenantal representation.

## Atonement: Non-Penal Influence versus Penal Substitution

### Schleiermacher’s non-penal atonement

- **No propitiation of wrath.** Because sin is not fundamentally law-breaking provoking divine wrath, there is no need for an atoning death as satisfaction of justice. God does not require satisfaction; he freely wills reconciliation.
- **Christ’s death as consummation of God-consciousness.** The cross is the supreme manifestation of Christ’s perfect God-consciousness—his absolute trust and surrender under conditions of extremity. Its salvific significance is intrinsic to his person, not a transaction with divine justice.
- **Soteriology as communication of a state.** Justification and reconciliation describe the **incorporation** of believers into the redemptive life of the community in which Christ’s God-consciousness is communicated and reproduced. They are descriptions of an ethical-religious process, not external forensic declarations.
- **No imputation in the Reformed sense.** The exchange “our sin to Christ; his righteousness to us” is reinterpreted as a historical-communal process of transformation, not a once-for-all forensic reckoning.

### Reformed penal substitution and imputation

In the Reformed scheme:

- **Objective problem: guilt and wrath.** Humanity stands under God’s just condemnation; the law pronounces a real sentence. The cross addresses an **objective forensic crisis**, not merely a subjective existential one.
- **Penal substitution.** Christ, as the last Adam and covenant head:
  - Bears the **penalty** of the law in the place of his people.
  - Endures the curse, satisfying divine justice and reconciling God to sinners.
  - Offers a vicarious obedience culminating in the cross, which is both sacrificial and penal.
- **Imputation.**
  - Our sins are imputed to Christ, not by infusion but by legal reckoning, so that he becomes liable to the penalty.
  - His righteousness (active and passive obedience) is imputed to believers, so that they are declared righteous in God’s court.
- **Forensic-then-renewal order.** Justification is an act, not a process; sanctification and renewed God-consciousness follow as fruits of union with Christ, not as the essence of reconciliation itself.

The clash is systematic: Schleiermacher collapses atonement into transformative participation in Christ’s consciousness; Reformed theology anchors transformation in a prior objective satisfaction of divine justice.

## Evaluation from a Reformed Confessional Perspective

- **Doctrine of sin.** Schleiermacher rightly recognizes sin as a pervasive condition and not merely discrete acts; however, by locating its essence in impaired God-consciousness, he severs it from its primary relation to God as Lawgiver and Judge and thereby evacuates the significance of guilt and wrath.
- **Christology.** His focus on Christ’s God-consciousness preserves something of the uniqueness and centrality of Christ but functionally subordinates the classical two-natures doctrine to a phenomenology of consciousness, undercutting its soteriological role as the ontological basis for substitution.
- **Atonement.** His rejection of penal substitution and imputation follows coherently from his redefinitions, but at the cost of:
  - Denying the biblical presentation of the cross as bearing curse, wrath, and punishment in the place of sinners.
  - Reducing reconciliation to a transformation of human religious experience rather than an objective change in our standing before God.
- **Order of being and knowing.** Schleiermacher reverses the Reformed order: instead of God’s external acts (covenant, incarnation, cross) giving rise to faith and piety, inward piety becomes the principium for reconstructing doctrine, including sin and atonement.

In sum, Schleiermacher’s account of sin as disturbance of God-consciousness and of Christ and atonement as the communication of perfect God-consciousness stands in principled opposition to the Reformed doctrines of guilt, wrath, penal substitution, imputation, and a robustly ontological Christology that together affirm that Christ objectively bore the law’s curse in the sinner’s place.

top_exam_questions.question: You say Schleiermacher reduces doctrine to the historical self-expression of communal God-consciousness. From a Reformed standpoint, how exactly does that differ from the confessional claim that doctrine is the church’s summary of Scripture? Where, precisely, does Schleiermacher cross the line into subjectivism?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Doctrinal location of the difference

There is a superficial similarity between Schleiermacher and classic Reformed confessionalism: both say doctrine is, in some sense, the church’s product. The crucial differences lie in:

- the **ontological status of revelation**;
- the **epistemic authority** of Scripture versus experience;
- the **direction of derivation** between revelation, faith, and doctrine.

In Reformed confessionalism:

- **Revelation is objectively given**: God speaks and acts, climactically in Christ, inscripturated in the prophetic and apostolic writings.
- **Scripture is principium cognoscendi externum**: the external, divinely authored, sufficient and normative rule of faith and life.
- **Doctrine is derivative and ministerial**: it is the church’s fallible, revisable summary of what Scripture teaches, normed by Scripture and rejected where contrary to Scripture.

In Schleiermacher:

- **Revelation collapses into piety**: what is “given” is not primarily God’s verbal self-disclosure but the feeling of absolute dependence and its development in the community.
- **Scripture is a classic document of piety**: paradigmatic for Christian consciousness, but not uniquely a verbally inspired divine rule.
- **Doctrine is constitutive self-description**: dogmas are “accounts” of Christian religious affections, not primarily assertions about divine realities “out there.”

The line into subjectivism is crossed at the level of what revelation is, and therefore what doctrine is about.

## Where the line is crossed

### Object of theology

Reformed theology:

- The object of theology is the **Triune God as he is in himself and for us**, known by analogical but real knowledge from his self-revelation in Christ and Scripture.
- Religious experience is **effect and confirmation** of revelation, not its essence.

Schleiermacher:

- The operative object of theology becomes **Christian God-consciousness** as historically realized in the community.
- God as “Whence” is never known apart from, or prior to, this consciousness; the noumenal is effectively inaccessible.

The shift is from theology as **speech about God on the basis of his Word** to theology as **self-interpretation of Christian piety**. That is the first decisive move into subjectivism.

### Norming norm vs. normed norm

Reformed confessionalism distinguishes:

- **Norma normans**: Holy Scripture, God’s Word written, possessing intrinsic authority prior to and apart from the church’s reception.
- **Norma normata**: creeds and confessions, authoritative only as and because they echo Scripture.

On this view, the church does not constitute doctrine by its piety; it recognizes and summarizes divine teaching given antecedently in Scripture.

Schleiermacher:

- Treats Scripture and dogma as **expressions of the communal life of faith**, whose normativity is bound to their adequacy in articulating the piety of the community.
- The effective ultimate norm becomes **the actual state and telos of Christian consciousness**, with Scripture’s normativity mediated through its exemplary role in forming that consciousness.

Here the direction of authority is subtly reversed: rather than communal experience being judged by Scripture, Scripture is functionally judged according to its serviceability to Christian consciousness. That is the second clear step into subjectivism.

### Propositional content vs. experiential essence

Reformed theology:

- Holds that **God gives true propositional content** about himself (e.g., “God is,” “God is triune,” “Christ died for our sins”), even though our grasp is analogical and ectypal.
- Doctrines are primarily **truth-claims about God’s being and acts**, and only secondarily descriptions of our corresponding experience.

Schleiermacher:

- Explicitly subordinates metaphysical and historical claims to the **description of religious affections**.
- Doctrines are primarily **second-order accounts of inner experience**; their metaphysical reference is attenuated or bracketed.

At this point, truth is no longer indexed primarily to **correspondence with God’s self-speaking** but to the **faithful articulation of piety**. That redefinition of theological truth is a third decisive move into subjectivism.

## Precise contrast with “summary of Scripture”

When Reformed confessions call doctrine a “summary of Scripture,” they presuppose:

- **A fixed, canonically bounded, divinely authored text** that is revelation in a unique sense.
- **Asymmetry** between Scripture and the church: the church is taught, corrected, and reformed by Scripture; the church does not determine Scripture’s content or authority.
- **Logical and temporal priority**: what Christians are to believe is *already there* in Scripture as God’s teaching, before any communal experience or doctrinal formulation.

Schleiermacher, by contrast, treats:

- The Christian community’s **God-consciousness as logically prior**: Scripture and dogma are manifestations of that consciousness.
- The biblical canon’s distinctiveness as **historical and functional**, not as the speech of God that norms all religious consciousness.
- The doctrines of the church as **constitutive of what “Christianity” is** insofar as they describe and shape communal experience, not as subordinate echo of an already fixed divine Word.

Thus Schleiermacher crosses into subjectivism precisely when the **center of gravity moves from God’s external self-revelation to the community’s internal religious life**, with Scripture and doctrine recast as historically conditioned self-expressions of that life rather than as obedient summaries of a prior, objective, and norming divine speech.

Doctrinal location of the difference

There is a superficial similarity between Schleiermacher and classic Reformed confessionalism: both say doctrine is, in some sense, the church’s product. The crucial differences lie in:

  • the ontological status of revelation;
  • the epistemic authority of Scripture versus experience;
  • the direction of derivation between revelation, faith, and doctrine.

In Reformed confessionalism:

  • Revelation is objectively given: God speaks and acts, climactically in Christ, inscripturated in the prophetic and apostolic writings.
  • Scripture is principium cognoscendi externum: the external, divinely authored, sufficient and normative rule of faith and life.
  • Doctrine is derivative and ministerial: it is the church’s fallible, revisable summary of what Scripture teaches, normed by Scripture and rejected where contrary to Scripture.

In Schleiermacher:

  • Revelation collapses into piety: what is “given” is not primarily God’s verbal self-disclosure but the feeling of absolute dependence and its development in the community.
  • Scripture is a classic document of piety: paradigmatic for Christian consciousness, but not uniquely a verbally inspired divine rule.
  • Doctrine is constitutive self-description: dogmas are “accounts” of Christian religious affections, not primarily assertions about divine realities “out there.”

The line into subjectivism is crossed at the level of what revelation is, and therefore what doctrine is about.

Where the line is crossed

Object of theology

Reformed theology:

  • The object of theology is the Triune God as he is in himself and for us, known by analogical but real knowledge from his self-revelation in Christ and Scripture.
  • Religious experience is effect and confirmation of revelation, not its essence.

Schleiermacher:

  • The operative object of theology becomes Christian God-consciousness as historically realized in the community.
  • God as “Whence” is never known apart from, or prior to, this consciousness; the noumenal is effectively inaccessible.

The shift is from theology as speech about God on the basis of his Word to theology as self-interpretation of Christian piety. That is the first decisive move into subjectivism.

Norming norm vs. normed norm

Reformed confessionalism distinguishes:

  • Norma normans: Holy Scripture, God’s Word written, possessing intrinsic authority prior to and apart from the church’s reception.
  • Norma normata: creeds and confessions, authoritative only as and because they echo Scripture.

On this view, the church does not constitute doctrine by its piety; it recognizes and summarizes divine teaching given antecedently in Scripture.

Schleiermacher:

  • Treats Scripture and dogma as expressions of the communal life of faith, whose normativity is bound to their adequacy in articulating the piety of the community.
  • The effective ultimate norm becomes the actual state and telos of Christian consciousness, with Scripture’s normativity mediated through its exemplary role in forming that consciousness.

Here the direction of authority is subtly reversed: rather than communal experience being judged by Scripture, Scripture is functionally judged according to its serviceability to Christian consciousness. That is the second clear step into subjectivism.

Propositional content vs. experiential essence

Reformed theology:

  • Holds that God gives true propositional content about himself (e.g., “God is,” “God is triune,” “Christ died for our sins”), even though our grasp is analogical and ectypal.
  • Doctrines are primarily truth-claims about God’s being and acts, and only secondarily descriptions of our corresponding experience.

Schleiermacher:

  • Explicitly subordinates metaphysical and historical claims to the description of religious affections.
  • Doctrines are primarily second-order accounts of inner experience; their metaphysical reference is attenuated or bracketed.

At this point, truth is no longer indexed primarily to correspondence with God’s self-speaking but to the faithful articulation of piety. That redefinition of theological truth is a third decisive move into subjectivism.

Precise contrast with “summary of Scripture”

When Reformed confessions call doctrine a “summary of Scripture,” they presuppose:

  • A fixed, canonically bounded, divinely authored text that is revelation in a unique sense.
  • Asymmetry between Scripture and the church: the church is taught, corrected, and reformed by Scripture; the church does not determine Scripture’s content or authority.
  • Logical and temporal priority: what Christians are to believe is already there in Scripture as God’s teaching, before any communal experience or doctrinal formulation.

Schleiermacher, by contrast, treats:

  • The Christian community’s God-consciousness as logically prior: Scripture and dogma are manifestations of that consciousness.
  • The biblical canon’s distinctiveness as historical and functional, not as the speech of God that norms all religious consciousness.
  • The doctrines of the church as constitutive of what “Christianity” is insofar as they describe and shape communal experience, not as subordinate echo of an already fixed divine Word.

Thus Schleiermacher crosses into subjectivism precisely when the center of gravity moves from God’s external self-revelation to the community’s internal religious life, with Scripture and doctrine recast as historically conditioned self-expressions of that life rather than as obedient summaries of a prior, objective, and norming divine speech.

top_exam_questions.question: Explain how a Van Tilian, analogical epistemology of revelation undercuts Schleiermacher’s claim that all doctrinal propositions are secondary expressions of prior religious feeling. Why must God’s self-attesting Word, rather than religious consciousness, be epistemically basic?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Historical and Conceptual Background

Schleiermacher relocates the center of theology from God’s self‑communication to human religious consciousness. The basic datum is the **Gefühl der schlechthinnigen Abhängigkeit**—the pre‑reflective “feeling of absolute dependence.” Doctrines are then:

- Second‑order, reflective judgments about this prior piety.
- Historical, communal objectifications of an underlying God‑consciousness.
- Normatively guided by the original, paradigmatic God‑consciousness of Christ as mediated in Scripture, but not themselves immediately given by divine self‑revelation.

Epistemically, this is a subjectivist move. What is basic is not God speaking, but the human’s irreducible self‑affection as dependent; revelation becomes a construal of experience rather than the principium cognoscendi.

Cornelius Van Til, by contrast, operates with a fundamentally different starting point:

- **Metaphysically**: The triune God is the self‑contained ontological Trinity; all facts are created, interpreted, and sustained by him.
- **Epistemologically**: Image‑bearers know only analogically, by thinking God’s thoughts after him under the constraints of his revelation.
- **Revelationally**: God’s self‑attesting Word—general and special, culminating in Christ and inscripturated in Scripture—is the ultimate authority and the necessary condition for any true knowledge.

This framework directly undercuts Schleiermacher’s claim that doctrinal propositions are secondary, derivative expressions of something more primordial in us.

## Doctrinal Analysis: Analogical Knowledge and Epistemic Priority

### Analogical epistemology

For Van Til, the Creator–creature distinction is absolute. Consequently:

- God’s knowledge is **archetypal**: comprehensive, original, self‑interpreting.
- Human knowledge is **ectypal**: derivative, finite, receptive, always dependent on God’s prior interpretation.

“Analogy” does not mean mere similarity of psychological state between God and humans; it means that:

- Every true human judgment must correspond to God’s pre‑interpreted judgment about that same object.
- The form and content of true human thinking are normed by God’s interpretation given in revelation, not by immediate consciousness.

Therefore, the most basic epistemic relation is not subject–world or subject–feeling, but **creature–speaking Creator**. To put it differently: the original “given” is not undefined religious intuition, but a world already revelationally structured and a Word already interpretive of that world.

### Why religious feeling cannot be epistemically basic

From Van Til’s perspective, Schleiermacher’s scheme fails on several interlocking fronts.

- **Ontological misplacement.**  
  To treat the feeling of absolute dependence as primary is to invert the direction of dependence. The creature’s self‑consciousness is radically dependent on God’s prior act of creating, sustaining, and addressing the creature. Thus:
  
    - Religious consciousness is itself a *fruit* of revelation (and, in fallen man, of its suppression), not a pre‑revelational substrate out of which doctrine is fashioned.
    - To say that doctrine is a secondary “expression” of feeling is to detach it from the objective triune subject who speaks, and to re‑root it in an immanent psychological field.

- **No norm internal to feeling.**  
  Van Til insists that all interpretation is covenantally conditioned: either obedient or rebellious. Religious experience as such is:

    - Ambiguous and corruptible under sin.
    - Capable of generating mutually contradictory theologies (Christian, pantheist, deist) on the same basis of “dependence.”
  
  Without a prior, self‑attesting divine Word, there is no principled way to distinguish:
  
    - True God‑consciousness from idolatrous dependence on the immanent whole.
    - Christian piety from generic theistic or even non‑theistic awe.

  Doctrine cannot be *merely* a posterior clarification of a pre‑theological feeling; rather, doctrine is what identifies, judges, and norms the very “feeling” as either faith or unbelief.

- **Collapse into autonomy.**  
  Schleiermacher aims to safeguard Christianity from rationalism by rooting it in immediate piety. But by making the *subject’s* experience the locus of ultimacy, he makes human consciousness the final court of appeal regarding:

    - Which doctrines count as legitimate expressions of Christian feeling.
    - How biblical claims must be reshaped to remain “fitting” to modern consciousness.

  For Van Til, this is epistemic autonomy: man, not God’s Word, sits in judgment. Even if the language of dependence is retained, the functional principium is the self‑interpreting subject.

### The self‑attesting Word as epistemically basic

Van Til’s alternative insists that the principium of theology must be God’s self‑attestation:

- **Self‑attestation as necessary.**  
  Because God is the ultimate authority and interpreter of reality, any appeal beyond him to validate his Word would subordinate him to a higher standard. Thus:

    - Scripture cannot be grounded in religious feeling, historical criticism, or communal consensus without ceasing to be ultimate.
    - The Spirit’s witness does not generate authority from within feeling; it opens the eyes to recognize the inherent authority already present in God’s speech.

- **Revelation as principium, experience as consequent.**  
  In Reformed, Van Tilian terms:

    - The principium essendi of theology is the triune God.
    - The principium cognoscendi externum is the inscripturated Word.
    - Religious experience is the internal, existential correlate of this principium, not its source.

  Hence, doctrinal propositions are not second‑order *after* piety; they are the normative divine interpretation that creates and shapes true piety in the covenant community.

- **Analogy and dogma.**  
  Since human knowledge is analogical, we never possess God’s self‑knowledge. But analogical does not mean derivative from feeling; it means derivative from God’s interpretation accommodated in revelation. Therefore:

    - Dogmatic propositions (e.g., “God is triune,” “Christ died for our sins”) are genuine knowledge claims, grounded in God’s own speech.
    - Experiential appropriation of these claims is subsequent and derivative; feeling must be continually re‑formed by the given Word, not vice versa.

In this light, Schleiermacher’s reduction of doctrine to expressive symbols of prior feeling is precisely what analogical epistemology excludes: the created consciousness does not originate theology; it receives and echoes the theology already resident in God’s self‑interpretation.

## Evaluation

From a Van Tilian standpoint, Schleiermacher’s project is not corrected by adding some propositional content to religious feeling; it must be reversed in order of dependence:

- God’s ontological self‑sufficiency and interpretive primacy require that divine speech, not human consciousness, be first.
- The noetic effects of sin demand an external, authoritative Word to judge and renew religious experience.
- Analogical knowledge entails that theology is exegesis of God’s revelation, not expression of the church’s inner life.

Therefore, Schleiermacher’s claim that all doctrinal propositions are secondary expressions of prior religious feeling is undercut at the root, because in a Van Tilian, analogical epistemology, God’s self‑attesting Word is epistemically basic and religious consciousness is its derivative, fallible, and corrigible effect.

top_exam_questions.question: You criticize Schleiermacher’s marginalization of the Trinity. Using the Westminster Confession on God and the Holy Trinity, show why a Trinitarian appendix is not a harmless rearrangement but a fundamental doctrinal failure, and how this flows from his starting point in feeling and God as ‘Whence.’
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Historical and Dogmatic Setting

Schleiermacher’s relocation of the doctrine of the Trinity to an appendix in his *Glaubenslehre* is not merely an editorial decision. It discloses a re‑ordering of the entire material and principial structure of Christian theology. In classic Reformed dogmatics, typified by the Westminster Confession of Faith (WCF), God as triune is the principium essendi of theology, and Scripture—containing a Trinitarian economy of revelation and redemption—is the principium cognoscendi. Schleiermacher replaces this with the **Gefühl der schlechthinnigen Abhängigkeit** (feeling of absolute dependence) as the essence of piety and God as the undifferentiated “Whence” of that feeling.

This alternative starting point predetermines the place of the Trinity: what is primary is the universal structure of religious self‑consciousness; the Trinity appears only as a later, ecclesial, and highly mediated doctrinal construction. Hence its confinement to an appendix is not accidental but theologically necessary, given his principles.

## The Westminster Confession on God and the Holy Trinity

WCF II (“Of God, and of the Holy Trinity”) articulates a very different order.

### Simple and Triune from the Outset

WCF II.1 describes God first as the one, simple, infinite, eternal, immutable being. But this is not a pre‑Trinitarian deity. WCF II.3 immediately confesses:

- There is “in the unity of the Godhead” three persons “of one substance, power, and eternity.”
- The Father is “of none, neither begotten nor proceeding,” the Son “eternally begotten of the Father,” and the Spirit “eternally proceeding from the Father and the Son.”

Several implications follow.

- **Ontological primacy of the Trinity.** Reality itself is grounded in the triune being of God, not in an undifferentiated absolute. The “unity” confessed in II.1 exists only as the unity of Father, Son, and Spirit described in II.3. There is no theologically legitimate interval between an abstract theism and Trinitarian specification.
- **Principial role for all theology.** Because God is triune *in se*, all subsequent loci (creation, providence, covenant, redemption, worship) are Trinitarian from the ground up. The Trinity is not a superstructure erected on a prior religious consciousness; it is the ontological condition of any saving knowledge of God at all.

To push the Trinity to an appendix is therefore, in Westminster terms, to detach all previous doctrinal affirmations from their only proper subject: the triune Lord.

### The Trinity and Revelation

WCF I on Scripture presupposes and expresses a Trinitarian economy:

- Scripture is “given by inspiration of God” (I.2, I.4) according to 2 Timothy 3:16, a work elsewhere ascribed to the Spirit.
- Christ, the Son, is the central subject matter of Scripture (I.5, I.6).
- The Father’s will is revealed in the Son, by the Spirit, through the written Word.

Thus, revelation itself is intrinsically Trinitarian in source, content, and efficacy. To treat the Trinity as a late, optional conceptual refinement is to deny that one ever dealt with the *Christian* God in the prior theological argument.

## Schleiermacher’s Starting Point and its Logic

Schleiermacher’s method begins not from God’s self‑revelation in Word and Spirit, but from the structure of human religious consciousness.

- **Feeling of absolute dependence.** This is a pre‑conceptual, universal religious datum, accessible apart from explicit Christian revelation. Theology becomes a disciplined reflection on this feeling as it is concretely shaped in the Christian community.
- **God as “Whence.”** God is defined functionally as the mysterious causal ground of the feeling of dependence, the “Whence” of our being and consciousness. This “Whence” is not given with personal names and relations (Father, Son, Spirit) but as an indeterminate absolute.

From such a starting point:

- The fundamental divine predicate is not Fatherhood, Sonship, or Spiration, but “being‑Whence‑of‑our‑feeling.”
- Any specifically Trinitarian content must arise secondarily, as the community’s historical, symbolic articulation of its piety, not as the immediate content of revelation.

This is precisely why Schleiermacher cannot give the Trinity constitutive dogmatic status. It does not belong to the essence of “Christian self‑consciousness” in abstraction, but to a later, conceptual elaboration of that consciousness.

## Why the Appendix Placement is Doctrinally Destructive

Measured by Westminster’s doctrinal architecture, the appendix placement signals at least three failures.

### Failure of Theology Proper

If theology proper is not from the outset about Father, Son, and Spirit, it is not about the true God.

- In WCF terms, God’s “incommunicable attributes” (II.1) are those of the triune being. To predicate them of an undifferentiated Whence is a formal abstraction, evacuating them of their proper hypostatic bearers.
- Schleiermacher’s Whence is, structurally, closer to a metaphysical absolute than to the living Lord who speaks, covenants, judges, and redeems as Father through the Son in the Spirit.

The result is that the God presupposed by his system is not, in Westminster’s sense, the God of the gospel.

### Failure in Christology and Soteriology

WCF VIII grounds redemption in the eternal relation of the Son to the Father and the mission of the Spirit:

- The Mediator is “the only begotten Son of God… of one substance, and equal with the Father” (VIII.2), who, in time, assumes human nature.
- The Spirit applies the redemption purchased by Christ (VIII.8; X.1).

If, as in Schleiermacher, Christ is primarily the one with perfect God‑consciousness in whom the community participates, then:

- The uniqueness of Christ is primarily religious‑psychological, not ontological and hypostatic.
- The Spirit’s work becomes the communication of Christ’s God‑consciousness rather than the efficacious application of a forensic, once‑for‑all atonement accomplished by the incarnate Son.

This reconfiguration is enabled by a weak doctrine of personal distinctions in God. Once the hypostatic identity of the Son as true God from true God is de‑centered, the atonement can be reinterpreted in experiential terms without overtly denying the Trinity, which has already been marginalized.

### Failure of Worship and Piety

WCF XXI insists that worship is offered to God “the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.” Christian piety is fundamentally:

- Addressed to the Father.
- Through the Son as Mediator.
- In the Holy Spirit’s enabling and indwelling.

Schleiermacher’s piety is structurally non‑Trinitarian at its core:

- The primal religious act is not invocation of Father through Son in the Spirit, but receptivity to the immediate feeling of dependence on the Whence.
- Trinitarian forms in liturgy and creed become expressive symbols of that basic feeling rather than the concrete names of the God who has named himself.

This turns the Trinity into the language of our highest religious experience rather than the condition and content of that experience given by revelation.

## Structural Contrast of Principles

The contrast can be summarized as a clash of starting points.

- **Westminster:**  
  - Ontological principle: The triune God (II.3).  
  - Epistemic principle: God’s self‑revelation in Scripture (I), which testifies to Christ by the Spirit.  
  - Experiential consequence: Faith and piety are fruits of the Word and Spirit, shaped by the Trinitarian economy.
- **Schleiermacher:**  
  - Ontological principle: An unqualified Whence of dependence.  
  - Epistemic principle: Analysis of Christian self‑consciousness and its historical development.  
  - Doctrinal consequence: The Trinity is a secondary, communal reflection on experience, not the principial content of revelation.

Given Schleiermacher’s premises, an appendix location for the Trinity is coherent. Measured by Westminster’s doctrine of the triune God, it is a systemic failure, because it indicates that everything prior in the system has not truly been about the triune Lord who alone is the object of Christian faith, worship, and salvation.

  • The Mediator is “the only begotten Son of God… of one substance, and equal with the Father” (VIII.2), who, in time, assumes human nature.
  • The Spirit applies the redemption purchased by Christ (VIII.8; X.1).

If, as in Schleiermacher, Christ is primarily the one with perfect God‑consciousness in whom the community participates, then:

  • The uniqueness of Christ is primarily religious‑psychological, not ontological and hypostatic.
  • The Spirit’s work becomes the communication of Christ’s God‑consciousness rather than the efficacious application of a forensic, once‑for‑all atonement accomplished by the incarnate Son.

This reconfiguration is enabled by a weak doctrine of personal distinctions in God. Once the hypostatic identity of the Son as true God from true God is de‑centered, the atonement can be reinterpreted in experiential terms without overtly denying the Trinity, which has already been marginalized.

Failure of Worship and Piety

WCF XXI insists that worship is offered to God “the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.” Christian piety is fundamentally:

  • Addressed to the Father.
  • Through the Son as Mediator.
  • In the Holy Spirit’s enabling and indwelling.

Schleiermacher’s piety is structurally non‑Trinitarian at its core:

  • The primal religious act is not invocation of Father through Son in the Spirit, but receptivity to the immediate feeling of dependence on the Whence.
  • Trinitarian forms in liturgy and creed become expressive symbols of that basic feeling rather than the concrete names of the God who has named himself.

This turns the Trinity into the language of our highest religious experience rather than the condition and content of that experience given by revelation.

Structural Contrast of Principles

The contrast can be summarized as a clash of starting points.

  • Westminster:
  • Ontological principle: The triune God (II.3).
  • Epistemic principle: God’s self‑revelation in Scripture (I), which testifies to Christ by the Spirit.
  • Experiential consequence: Faith and piety are fruits of the Word and Spirit, shaped by the Trinitarian economy.
  • Schleiermacher:
  • Ontological principle: An unqualified Whence of dependence.
  • Epistemic principle: Analysis of Christian self‑consciousness and its historical development.
  • Doctrinal consequence: The Trinity is a secondary, communal reflection on experience, not the principial content of revelation.

Given Schleiermacher’s premises, an appendix location for the Trinity is coherent. Measured by Westminster’s doctrine of the triune God, it is a systemic failure, because it indicates that everything prior in the system has not truly been about the triune Lord who alone is the object of Christian faith, worship, and salvation.

Then defend penal substitution and imputation from a Reformed perspective, showing how Schleiermacher’s hamartiology must be rejected at a foundational level.
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Schleiermacher’s doctrine of sin as disturbance of God-consciousness

Schleiermacher’s hamartiology is strictly coordinated with his definition of religion. Religion, for him, is not primarily doctrine, ethics, or metaphysics, but **Gefühl**: the pre-reflective **feeling of absolute dependence**. This “God-consciousness” is the primal datum of piety and the formal essence of religion.

Within that framework:

- **God-consciousness as norm.** The essence of true humanity is a clear, uninterrupted God-consciousness, the awareness of ourselves as absolutely dependent on the “Whence” of our being.
- **Christ as the archetype.** Jesus is sinless not because of legal conformity to an external law, but because in him the God-consciousness is perfect, constant, and victorious over every opposing tendency. He is “the Redeemer” as the one in whom this God-consciousness is archetypally realized.
- **Sin as disturbance.** Sin is not first a transgression of divine law, but a **disturbance, obscuring, or inhibition** of the God-consciousness by the “self-consciousness” of relative independence. The human subject experiences tension between God-relatedness and world/self-relatedness; sin is that structure in which the latter suppresses the former.
- **Guilt as self-discrepancy.** What is called “guilt” is the consciousness of one’s life as out of harmony with the normative God-consciousness. It is experienced as spiritual dissonance rather than primarily as liability to retributive judgment before a personal Lawgiver.

Redemption, therefore, is the **restoration and propagation** of Christ’s perfect God-consciousness within the communal life of believers (the Gemeinde). Atonement is not satisfaction of divine justice but the historical-communal mediation of Christ’s piety to us, such that the disturbance is gradually overcome.

## Why penal substitution is incoherent on Schleiermacher’s premises

Given this anthropology and hamartiology, penal substitutionary atonement becomes conceptually misaligned at several points.

- **No primary legal relation.** If the fundamental God–human relation is not juridical (Creator–Lawgiver to accountable covenant-breaker) but experiential (absolute dependence disclosed in consciousness), then “law,” “guilt,” and “penalty” cannot be ontologically basic. They are, at most, derivative descriptions of disturbed piety. A substitutionary bearing of penalty presupposes law and sanctions as structurally basic to the relation between God and humanity; Schleiermacher denies this.
- **Sin not essentially demerit.** If sin is first a **privation or disordered state of consciousness**, not inherently a culpable violation of a known command, then the notion of **retributive punishment** is displaced by the notion of **therapeutic restoration**. Penalty belongs to justice; restoration belongs to healing. One does not “punish” a disturbance; one corrects or cures it.
- **Christ’s work as communication, not satisfaction.** Schleiermacher treats Christ’s redemptive efficacy as the **communication of his God-consciousness** to the community. The saving event is the emergence and contagion of Christ’s piety, not the endurance of wrath. Penal substitution, conversely, treats Christ’s cross as the once-for-all **judicial act** where God’s wrath against sin is borne and exhausted. Under Schleiermacher’s scheme, such an act is not needed, because God is not primarily a Judge whose law has been violated but the Whence in relation to whom our consciousness is disordered.
- **Doctrine as expression of piety.** Since doctrines are historically conditioned expressions of communal God-consciousness, talk of “Christ bearing our penalty” is reduced to a symbolic or mythic construal of how Christ’s piety reorders ours. It cannot retain the status of an event in God’s own judicial action.

Thus, on Schleiermacher’s own first principles, penal substitution appears incoherent: it imports an alien forensic scheme into what he construes as essentially experiential and therapeutic categories.

## Reformed defense of penal substitution and imputation

From a classic Reformed standpoint, Schleiermacher errs not at the periphery but at the foundations of hamartiology, with direct implications for atonement and justification.

### Reformed hamartiology: sin as lawlessness

Reformed theology begins with the **personal, covenantal God** who speaks and commands, not with religious experience as such.

- **Sin as transgression of divine law.** Sin is defined fundamentally as **lawlessness**, a violation of God’s revealed will. This includes both corruption of nature and concrete acts contrary to the moral law.
- **Original and actual sin.** Humanity in Adam stands under a real covenantal arrangement; Adam’s fall entails both:
    - a **forensic condition** (guilt, liability to curse), and  
    - a **moral condition** (depravity, inward corruption).
- **Guilt as liability before a Judge.** Guilt is not merely self-discrepancy; it is objective liability to divine retribution. Feelings of guilt may register this, but do not constitute it.

Affective and experiential disturbance are real, but they presuppose an objective breach of divine law.

### Penal substitution as coherent on Reformed premises

Within that framework, penal substitution is not an optional metaphor but an entailment of God’s justice.

- **God’s justice and wrath.** As holy and righteous, God must oppose and punish sin. His wrath is not caprice but the necessary judicial stance of the moral Governor toward lawbreaking.
- **Substitutionary structure.** In the covenant of grace, Christ stands as **mediator and surety** for his people:
    - He assumes their legal place under the law.
    - Their sins are **imputed** to him; he bears their penalty.
    - His righteousness is **imputed** to them; they are counted righteous.
- **Cross as judicial event.** The crucifixion is thus a real **forensic transaction** in history: God publicly condemns sin in the flesh of his Son, so that he might be just and the justifier of the ungodly who believe.

This satisfies divine justice, turns aside wrath, and grounds reconciliation objectively prior to its subjective appropriation in faith.

### Imputation and union with Christ

Reformed theology also integrates experiential transformation, but as consequent, not constitutive, of justification.

- **Union with Christ.** By the Spirit, believers are united to Christ. In that union:
    - There is a **legal participation**: Christ’s status becomes theirs (justification).
    - There is a **moral participation**: Christ’s life is communicated to them (sanctification).
- **Double imputation.** The righteousness counted to believers is not their God-consciousness but Christ’s obedience fulfilled under the law. Likewise, their guilt laid on Christ is not mere existential alienation but actual culpability for specific violations of divine law.

Thus, what Schleiermacher locates in the communication of Christ’s piety, Reformed theology locates first in a **forensic exchange** and then in the Spirit-wrought renewal that flows from it.

## Foundational critique of Schleiermacher’s hamartiology

The Reformed rejection of Schleiermacher is not a quibble about atonement models; it is a rejection of his starting point.

- **Wrong epistemic foundation.** By treating religious self-consciousness as the norm, Schleiermacher effectively subjects God’s self-revelation in Scripture to the tribunal of experience. This undermines the givenness of divine law and the clarity of God’s judicial claims.
- **Reduction of sin.** Sin becomes primarily a functional or phenomenological disturbance within consciousness, rather than an objective violation of a personal Lord. This trivializes the gravity of sin and makes retributive justice seem inappropriate or even immoral.
- **Dilution of divine holiness.** If God is conceived mainly as the Whence of dependence rather than the holy Lawgiver and Judge, the cross cannot be the place where divine justice is vindicated. The holiness that requires satisfaction is marginalized.
- **Collapse of justification into sanctification.** Schleiermacher’s emphasis on the communication of Christ’s God-consciousness blurs the line between:
    - an external, definitive **declaration** of righteousness, and  
    - an internal, progressive **renewal** of the subject.
  
Reformed theology insists that justification is by imputed righteousness, extra nos, received by faith alone, precisely because sin is first a legal problem.

In sum, Schleiermacher’s doctrine of sin as mere disturbance of God-consciousness must be rejected because only when sin is understood as real transgression of God’s holy law does penal substitution and the imputation of Christ’s righteousness faithfully articulate the biblical and Reformed gospel.

top_exam_questions.question: You conflate titles when referring to ‘On Christian Religion’ and the placement of the Trinity in an appendix. Can you clearly distinguish between On Religion: Speeches to its Cultured Despisers and The Christian Faith, and explain how Schleiermacher’s thought develops between these works?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Historical setting and basic distinction of the two works

Schleiermacher’s two key dogmatic works are distinct both in genre and in historical-theological function.

- **On Religion: Speeches to its Cultured Despisers (1799; revised later)** is an apologetic and programmatic work. Its audience is the Romantic intelligentsia alienated from both rationalist orthodoxy and Enlightenment deism. Its genre is rhetorical, literary, and largely non-systematic.
- **The Christian Faith (Der christliche Glaube; 1st ed. 1821–22; 2nd ed. 1830–31)** is a full-scale dogmatics. Its audience is the theological academy and church. Its genre is strictly systematic and methodological, presented as a “Christian doctrine” ordered according to the inner structure of Christian piety.

The oft-cited relegation of the Trinity to an appendix belongs to **The Christian Faith**, not to the Speeches. In the dogmatics, the doctrine of the Trinity is treated only at the end and is explicitly said not to arise directly from the self-consciousness of faith in the same way as the central loci; therefore it is formally appended.

## On Religion: Speeches – early program

In the **Speeches**, Schleiermacher is still staking out the basic terrain of “religion” in opposition to both rationalist dogmatism and moralism.

- The central concept is **religion as Anschauung und Gefühl**: immediate intuition and feeling of the universe, prior to and distinct from metaphysics (knowing) and ethics (doing).
- Religion is defined as a mode of **immediate consciousness of the infinite** within the finite, a receptive orientation to dependence, contingency, and unity with the whole.
- Christianity appears here more as the **highest and purest form** of this general religious consciousness, but the construction remains relatively **universalistic and romantic**: religions are expressions of a single underlying essence of piety.
- Christ is important but not yet technically central as Redeemer; he is paradigmatic for the purity and fullness of religious intuition, but the Christology is not yet the formal hinge of the system.
- Scripture and dogma are considered secondary, historical expressions of this basic religious life; the emphasis lies on **inner piety** and the individuality of religious self-expression.

The Speeches already contain the decisive turn to **subjectivity** and **immediacy of religious consciousness**, but they are not yet tightly structured around the “feeling of absolute dependence,” nor limited in scope to explicitly Christian dogmatics.

## The Christian Faith – mature dogmatic system

By contrast, **The Christian Faith** gives a systematic account of specifically **Christian** doctrine as the conceptual articulation of a distinct form of piety.

- The formal principle is now explicitly the **Gefühl schlechthinniger Abhängigkeit**: the feeling of absolute dependence characterizing human self-consciousness before God.
- Theology is strictly **positive**: it expounds the doctrinal self-understanding of the Christian community arising from its peculiar God-consciousness, not religion in general.
- The entire dogmatic structure is organized around:
  - The **God–world relation** as experienced in absolute dependence.
  - The **consciousness of sin** as a disturbance of God-consciousness.
  - The **redemption in Christ**, who uniquely possesses a perfect, constant God-consciousness communicated to the community.
- Christology and soteriology move to the center: Christ is the **Ursprungsorgan** (original organ) of redemption; the church’s piety derives from participation in his God-consciousness.
- Doctrines become **reflections on the states of Christian consciousness**:
  - Doctrine is the second-order, conceptual expression of what is first a lived piety of the church.
  - Propositions are historical, revisable articulations whose normativity is relative to their ability to express the communal God-consciousness given in Christ.
- The **Trinity** appears only at the end, as a conceptual synthesis of the economic relations presupposed in Christian piety (God as Creator, Redeemer in Christ, Sanctifier in the Spirit), but Schleiermacher insists it does not stand at the origin of Christian self-consciousness in the same immediate way as redemption in Christ; hence its formal placement in an appendix.

## Development from the Speeches to The Christian Faith

There is both continuity and significant development between the two works.

### Continuities

- **Primacy of experience**: In both, theology is grounded in lived piety rather than in speculative metaphysics or ecclesiastical authority.
- **Anti-metaphysical posture**: Both oppose a natural-theological or rationalist grounding of doctrine; God is not object of theoretical cognition but of immediate consciousness.
- **Historical consciousness**: Both see religious expressions (including doctrines) as historically mediated and culturally shaped.

### Developments and shifts

- **From general religion to specifically Christian dogmatics**:
  - Speeches treat “religion” in broad, comparative, and apologetic terms, with Christianity as the highest religious form.
  - The Christian Faith confines itself to the **positive content of Christian faith** as lived in the church; it is not a philosophy of religion, but a dogmatics.

- **From romantic intuition to structured God-consciousness**:
  - In the Speeches, “intuition and feeling of the universe” suggests a more open, aesthetic, and plural religious sensibility.
  - In The Christian Faith, this is disciplined into the more precise notion of **absolute dependence on God**, tied to created finitude and ordered by the Christ-event; the phenomenology of consciousness is more rigorously construed.

- **Christological concentration**:
  - The Speeches do not yet consistently derive religion’s norm from Christ’s unique person; Christ exemplifies religion but is not yet structurally indispensable.
  - The Christian Faith makes **Christ’s perfect God-consciousness** the decisive center: Christianity is the community arising from and sharing in this consciousness, and all dogma explicates that reality.

- **Doctrinal architecture and the Trinity**:
  - In the Speeches, there is no full dogmatic framework; hence no systematic placement of the Trinity.
  - In The Christian Faith, Schleiermacher carefully expounds the loci (God, creation, providence, sin, Christ, church, etc.) as expressions of Christian self-consciousness; the Trinity appears only as a **derivative conceptual schema** distilled from the economic relations already described.
  - Thus, the subordinate placement of the Trinity is not an arbitrary slight but follows from his methodological axiom: only what directly arises from the inner structure of Christian piety belongs to the body of dogmatics; what is a reflective synthesis (like the Nicene formula) is formally appended.

- **Methodological rigor**:
  - The Speeches are occasional, persuasive, and impressionistic.
  - The Christian Faith is self-consciously **scientific theology**, with strict criteria:
    - Theology describes the **self-consciousness of the Christian communion**.
    - Doctrines are valid insofar as they accurately render this consciousness in conceptual form.
    - No locus is admitted that cannot be tied back to the piety of absolute dependence as mediated through Christ.

In sum, Schleiermacher moves from a Romantic, broadly religious apologetic in On Religion to a rigorously structured, Christologically centered dogmatics in The Christian Faith, where his phenomenology of Christian consciousness governs the entire system and leads him to relegate the Trinity to an appendix as a secondary conceptualization of relations already implicit in redeemed piety.

    • Doctrines are valid insofar as they accurately render this consciousness in conceptual form.
    • No locus is admitted that cannot be tied back to the piety of absolute dependence as mediated through Christ.

In sum, Schleiermacher moves from a Romantic, broadly religious apologetic in On Religion to a rigorously structured, Christologically centered dogmatics in The Christian Faith, where his phenomenology of Christian consciousness governs the entire system and leads him to relegate the Trinity to an appendix as a secondary conceptualization of relations already implicit in redeemed piety.

## Restatement of the Issue

The weakness is this: I objected to Schleiermacher’s subordination of doctrine to religious feeling by appealing to Scripture’s propositional revelation, but I did not engage his central claim that all doctrinal propositions are necessarily derivative expressions of a pre-conceptual “feeling of absolute dependence.” I simply asserted the contrary Reformed view instead of showing where Schleiermacher’s argument about the priority of feeling over doctrine breaks down.

## Schleiermacher’s Argument on Doctrine and Feeling

Schleiermacher’s key moves can be summarized as follows:

- Religion, in its essence, is neither metaphysics (knowing) nor ethics (doing), but **Gefühl**: the immediate, pre-reflective consciousness of absolute dependence.
- Doctrines are not direct divine information but **reflective, linguistic objectifications** of this prior piety in the Christian community.
- Therefore, any putative “propositional revelation” is, at best, a historically conditioned self-description of communal God-consciousness, not an immediate divine self-communication in conceptual form.

On this account, to claim that Scripture gives us primary, divinely authored propositions is already to have mistaken the derivative for the original.

## Reformed Critique of Schleiermacher’s Reasoning

From a classic Reformed standpoint, the issue is not merely that Schleiermacher reaches different conclusions, but that his epistemological starting point precludes God’s sovereign freedom to address us.

### Misidentification of the Essence of Religion

Schleiermacher defines the essence of religion in terms of human consciousness rather than God’s self-initiated relation.

- Biblically and confessionally, **religion is covenantal relation grounded in God’s speech-acts**, not first an immanent structure of human consciousness.
- To say that feeling is “essential” and doctrine “derivative” presupposes that the human subject is the constitutive center; but in Scripture, God’s Word creates, judges, and renews the human subject. The order is not: subject → feeling → doctrine, but: God’s self-communication → created and renewed consciousness → doctrinal confession.

Thus Schleiermacher’s argument begs the question against a revelational ontology and epistemology.

### Illicit Restriction to Immediacy of Consciousness

Schleiermacher makes **immediacy to consciousness** the criterion of what is original in religion. Anything mediated by concepts, language, or history is deemed secondary.

- This reduction assumes that whatever is mediated conceptually cannot be original revelation. But in Scripture, **the Word of God is inherently linguistic and historical**; divine immediacy is not threatened but realized through God’s freely chosen mediations (prophets, apostles, Christ’s human words).
- The Reformed view holds that the Spirit can make **mediated, conceptual words** the primary medium of divine presence and address. The alternative—only what is pre-conceptual is religiously primary—is not an empirical discovery but a romantic-idealist axiom.

So Schleiermacher’s dismissal of propositional revelation rests on a philosophical restriction, not on neutral phenomenological description.

### Collapse of Divine Objectivity into Communal Consciousness

If all doctrines are nothing but the community’s reflective articulation of its own feeling, then:

- The **referent** of doctrine (the triune God, the history of redemption, the person and work of Christ) becomes functionally indistinguishable from the community’s evolving self-understanding.
- The Trinity, for example, is no longer a synthetically revealed reality that corrects and judges the church’s consciousness, but an especially refined expression of that consciousness.

From a Reformed perspective, this undercuts the **critical function of revelation**: God’s Word stands over against the church, calling it to repentance, reform, and doctrinal correction. Schleiermacher’s framework lacks the stable, extra-subjective norm necessary for such divine judgment.

### Failure to Account for the Normativity and Stability of Scripture

Schleiermacher must explain why the biblical witness, itself a historical product, has canonical, enduring authority.

- If Scripture is only a privileged record of early Christian God-consciousness, then its **normativity** is grounded, at most, in historical primacy or paradigmatic intensity of feeling.
- But in the Reformed account, the canon’s authority is grounded in **God’s own intention and authorship**: the same Spirit who inspires the text also illumines the church to receive it as a Word from outside its consciousness.

Schleiermacher’s model can describe influence, but not genuine, lasting **obligation** to particular doctrinal contents as God’s speech.

### Inadequate Ontology of Divine Freedom and Personality

By confining revelation to the form of human feeling, Schleiermacher implicitly denies that God may **freely choose to speak conceptually** and identify himself in determinate ways (e.g., as Father, Son, and Spirit).

- Reformed theology insists that **God is a speaking Lord**, who can and does bind us to his self-interpretation in words and acts.
- Schleiermacher’s position treats any such determinate divine self-identification as a product of our consciousness, rather than a free act of God that confronts and reshapes that consciousness.

This fails to do justice to the biblical pattern of a living, personal God who initiates covenant by promising, commanding, and interpreting his own deeds.

## Positive Reformed Alternative

From a confessional Reformed standpoint:

- Religious experience, including a sense of dependence, is **real but derivative**: it is the Spirit’s work in us in response to the **objective Word**.
- Doctrinal propositions are not mere expressions of prior feeling; they are **Spirit-given articulations of God’s own testimony** concerning himself and his saving work.
- Scripture’s propositional content is therefore both:
    - historically and linguistically mediated, and
    - ontologically and epistemically primary as God’s speech that generates, norms, and corrects the experience and piety of the church.

Thus Schleiermacher’s mistake lies not simply in undervaluing Scripture’s propositions, but in an a priori reordering of God–human relations that reverses the biblical sequence of God’s speaking and our believing.

In sum, Schleiermacher’s argument fails because it illegitimately makes human religious consciousness the constitutive ground of doctrine, whereas in classic Reformed theology doctrine is grounded in God’s sovereign self-revelation that precedes, norms, and judges all religious experience.

logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The identified weakness is this: I affirmed that our knowledge of God is analogical and incomplete, and then simply asserted that this is enough to reject Schleiermacher’s grounding of theology in religious experience (Gefühl, God-consciousness). What I did not adequately show is why, given that our knowledge is indeed analogical and limited, the primary norm for theology must still be revealed propositional content (Word) rather than the subject’s experience of dependence, with doctrine merely articulating that experience.

## Doctrinal analysis: analogical knowledge and primacy of the Word

From a classic Reformed standpoint, three clarifications are decisive.

### Analogical knowledge does not collapse into subjectivism

To say our knowledge of God is analogical and ectypal means:

- God’s being and knowledge are archetypal, incommunicable in se; we never grasp God as God knows himself.
- Nevertheless, God freely accommodates himself, giving true knowledge in human concepts and sentences, especially in Scripture.

This has two implications Schleiermacher cannot absorb:

- **Truth is indexed to God’s self-communication, not to our inner states.** The adequacy of a doctrinal statement is measured by its conformity (under the Spirit) to God’s revealed Word, not by its successful articulation of a prior experiential feeling.
- **Analogical does not mean constructed from below.** Our conceptual content is derivative of God’s speaking, not of our religious self-awareness. The “analogy” is God-to-us, not us-to-God.

Schleiermacher reverses that direction: the basic given is the feeling of absolute dependence; any God-language is a reflective expression of that experiential datum. By contrast, in Reformed theology, the basic given is God’s address (in creation and supremely in Scripture); religious experience is the Spirit’s effect of that address in the subject.

### Why propositional revelation is principial, not derivative

The principiality of Word over experience rests on three loci: revelation, faith, and the Spirit’s work.

- **Revelation.**  
    - General revelation: the created order and conscience already communicate divine truth “from above,” independent of how any given subject feels about it. Human experience is a response to, not the source of, this revelation.  
    - Special revelation: Scripture is God’s covenantal speech-act, given objectively in history, containing determinate claims about God, man, Christ, and salvation.
- **Faith.**  
    - Faith is defined as knowledge, assent, and trust in the divine testimony. Its content-element presupposes prior propositional givenness: a promise believed, a Christ confessed, a God worshiped under specific names and attributes.  
    - The reflexive awareness “I am utterly dependent” is, in biblical terms, already an interpreted experience, normed and activated by prior divine speaking.
- **The Spirit.**  
    - The Spirit’s internal work does not generate its own content; it illumines, seals, and applies the content of the Word.  
    - Subjective piety is therefore formally derivative of revelation, not co-ordinate with it, let alone its source.

Thus even if all our God-talk is analogical, the direction of dependence remains: experience is normed by God’s speech, not God’s speech by experience.

### Why Schleiermacher’s order cannot be simply baptized as “analogical”

Schleiermacher can readily acknowledge that all God-talk is conditioned, finite, historically mediated. The crux is not finitude but normativity and origin.

- For Schleiermacher:
    - The primitive fact is the feeling of absolute dependence.  
    - “God” names the Whence of that feeling.  
    - Doctrines are second-order expressions of the community’s piety, revisable as that piety historically develops.

- From a Reformed standpoint:
    - The primitive fact is God’s self-revelation in his works and Word.  
    - Human consciousness of dependence is itself a fruit of that objective revelation plus the Spirit’s regenerating and illuminating work.  
    - Doctrines are the church’s obedient, revisable but truth-aimed confession of what God has said, not self-expressions of communal feeling.

The difference is not whether our formulations are historically situated; it is whether theology’s basic normative reference is God’s speaking or the community’s piety. Analogical knowledge is entirely compatible with the claim that God has given binding, contentful testimony to himself which judges our experience, rather than being generated by it.

## Evaluation: why analogical propositional knowledge must be primary

Given the above, the move beyond Schleiermacher is not: “our knowledge is analogical, therefore not purely experiential.” Rather:

- Because knowledge is analogical, only God can determine how he will be known; this determination occurs in revelation, not in our internal states.
- Because revelation is covenantal speech, the church is bound to its content as primary norm; religious experience is genuine but is to be tested and interpreted by that content.
- Therefore, any theological method that treats doctrine as a derivative expression of piety, rather than as the disciplined reception and articulation of God’s prior Word, reverses the Lord–servant relation in knowledge and collapses theology into anthropology.

In classic Reformed terms, then, the primacy of analogical propositional revelation over subjectivity follows precisely from divine aseity and Lordship in revelation: God’s freely given Word, not our feeling, must be the principial and normative starting point for theology.
